description:
6:00 - 6:30 Participants arrive and socialize. 

6:30 - 6:45 Group introductions and announcements from participants and organizers.

6:45 - 8:45 Hacking. Project teams break out to work.  New participants can join teams, circulate, or seek out the Co-Captains for orientation (Justin, Matt, or Leah).

~7:30 Food delivered. 

8:45 - 9:00 Everyone reconvenes and shares reactions to and progress made over the last two hours. Show and tell if time/resources allow it. Thank you and goodnight.

9:00 Sometimes an after party (Happy Hour)

Notes: 

• Text Matt 202-330-1154 or Justin at 301-538-5812 if you have problems.

• Bring cash for food and drink! Pay what you can (but remember we only have a single sponsor that covers a small amount of our expenses: servers, food, etc)

• Bring a laptop (it’s ok if you can’t) and review list of active projects: http://bit.ly/codefordc

If you are new to Code for DC… 

• Please take a look at our website http://www.codefordc.org 

• Next take a look at our active projects http://bit.ly/codefordc

• Review the Code for DC Code of Conduct (draft)https://github.com/codefordc/code-of-conduct

• If you are relatively new to civic hacking check out the Code for DC Getting Started Guide https://github.com/codefordc/getting-started

• Start working on a project with someone or bring your own project


• Introduce yourself to others

• If you had a good time join Google Group and Meetup
name: October 2014 Civic Hacknight 1

name: October 2014 Civic Hacknight 2

description:
DC Legal Hackers is the DC Chapter of a growing movement of more than twenty legal hacking, technology, or innovation groups around the country. 

A legal hacker is someone who cares about the intersection of law and technology and seeks to improve legal practice through technology while simultaneously using legal skills to promote technological innovation and exploration. 

Join us on Wednesday Oct 1, 2014 to legal hack crypto/ethereum law.

7-7:30 Food, drinks and networking  

7:30-7:45 Introductions and Announcements 

7:45 - 9:00 Presentations and Discussion

* Peter Van Valkenburgh, Tech Freedom, etc, @valkenburgh

* Casey Kulman, Open Technology Institute, etc, @compleatang

Follow along on twitter with the hashtag #LegalHack or at www.twitter.com/DCLegalHackers
name: #LegalHack Crypto / Ethereum Law

description:
DC Legal Hackers is the DC Chapter of a growing movement of more than twenty legal hacking, technology, or innovation groups around the country. 

A legal hacker is someone who cares about the intersection of law and technology and seeks to improve legal practice through technology while simultaneously using legal skills to promote technological innovation and exploration.

Our CopyNight in September was awesome, and there was a lot of interest in doing it regularly, so:

Join us on Wednesday, October 15, 2014 to legal hack copyright and bring back CopyNight to DC!

We will discuss a broad range of recent copyright issues (see, e.g., my list from last time), probably over pizza and beer again.

Location TBD.


Questions?  Suggestions?  Take this poll, and/or contact Ali at alisternburg@gmail.com or @alisternburg.
name: #LegalHack CopyNight Returns: October 15 Edition!

description:
Hack and Tell will be at WeWork Chinatown again in September! (Hooray!) Everyone is looking forward to hearing about *your* cool hack! Presentation signups are here:

http://bit.ly/presentatdc

The format is informal, engaging, and friendly: presenters have 5 minutes to show off their hack (it goes faster than you’d expect) and then the audience has 5 minutes to ask questions, make jokes, and suggest ideas and feedback. The hacks that people present are anything from how to train your dog to text you when it needs a walk to [something more serious... like 3d-printing aluminum parts]. Show us what you’ve got! But remember: no startup pitches, dull work projects, no deckware!

If you’re interested in presenting, complete this short form to let us know: http://bit.ly/presentatdc

See you at the meetup! We'll start close to seven. There may be a couple beers. It's going to be fun! :) Big thanks to WeWork for hosting us! We love WeWork! We love you! We love hacks! <3
name: Round 13: Triskaidekaphilia

description:
For our October Meetup, we're very pleased to have Jared Lander from NYC visit us to talk about Lasso regression. The Lasso is one of the most significant machine learning algorithms from the past 15 years. Conceived by Hastie, Tibshirani and Friedman from Stanford, the Lasso performs dimension reduction and variable selection, making it well suited for the high dimensionality of today's datasets. In this talk, Jared will go over some of the math behind the Lasso and discuss some recent advancements in performing statistical inference on Lasso-fitted models. He will also show the R code behind the results. This will be an engaging and highly informative presentation -- don't miss it!

Agenda:

• 6:30pm -- Networking, Empenadas, and Refreshments

• 7:00pm -- Introduction, Announcements, Give-aways

• 7:15pm -- Presentation and Discussion

• 8:30pm -- Data Drinks (Tonic, 2036 G St NW)

Bio:

Jared Lander is the Founder and CEO of Lander Analytics a data science consultancy based in New York City, the Organizer of the New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup and an Adjunct Professor of Statistics at Columbia University.  His work for both large and small organizations ranges from music and tech startups to finance and humanitarian relief efforts.  He is the author of R for Everyone: Advanced Analytics and Graphics, a book about R Programming geared toward Data Scientists and Non-Statisticians alike.

Sponsors:

This event is sponsored by the GWU Department of Decision Sciences, Pearson/InformIT, Cloudera, Statistics.com, LivingSocial, Novetta Solutions, Elder Research, and Five 9 Group.
name: Confidence in the Lasso

description:
For October, we'll be discussing four tech projects and their impact on local transportation issues. Doors open at 6:00 with pizza and drinks, and the presentations start at 6:30. 

• Trevor Gerhardt of Conveyal will show us their Transit Tech Initiative with Arlington County, specifically the "evaluating a commute" portion of the program.

• Eric Meyer will tell us about the Baltimore-based Haystack mobile app, which lets people buy and sell street-side parking spaces.

• Chase Donnelly and Peter Mazzeo will demo their new Boontrek app, which creates a community marketplace for ride sharing.


• Peter Shashkin and Vitaliy Fedonkin from EastBanc Technologies will show us TransitIQ, which analyzes transit data, detecting anomalies, bus bunching, and more. EastBanc works with SmarTrip cards and is the company behind developer.wmata.com.
name: Cool Mobility Apps: October Edition

description:
For our second Bike Hack Night, we're going to look at both software and hardware projects. We've got a great lineup, with more to be added:

• Betsy Emmons will show her animated MapStory on the history of bike lanes in DC.


• Lia Seremetis of DC Bike Party will talk about how we GPS-tracked a big bike ride and made an animation of it.

• Shane Farthing of WABA will demo their mobile app.


• BikeArlington will show us their upcoming app for creating a crowd-sourced map of bike racks.


• SocialBicycles will talk about their model of dockless bikesharing.

• Reg Viray from the Virginia Tech Transportation Institute will talk about bicycles and the future of connected vehicles.


• Ola Göransson from the Embassy of Sweden will show us the Hövding "invisible" helmet.


• Ted Ullrich of Tomorrow Lab in New York City will show us the WayCount device, which can be used to crowdsource bike traffic count data.

If you have a bike-related app or data visualization that's creative and local, we want to see it!

Please note there is a chance the location will be changed; we'll announce it later.

Read about the last Bike Hack Night: Transportation Techies Show What Can Be Done With Bike Data.
name: Bike Hack Night II

description:
Putting out the call for new and exciting apps and data visualizations about Capital Bikeshare. Read about CaBiHackNight I and CaBiHackNight II to get an idea of how it works. This is a "show and tell," not a hackathon. Got a cool CaBi project? We'd love to see it!

We'll add speakers here as folks sign up:

• Colin Hughes of the Institute for Transportation and Development Policy will talk about planning principles for bikeshare systems.

• Trevor Gerhardt will show us a dcjs data explorer for CaBi.

• Mathias Hansen will show us how he visualizes an individual's trip histories with his Trip statistics app.

• Paul DeMaio, the program manager of Arlington's Capital Bikeshare service, will share a study on CaBi’s first-mile/last-mile ridership.
name: CaBi Hack Night III

description:
DCFemTech would love to announce our Tour de Code, a collaboration with dozens of organizations (Women Who Code, Startup Weekend, Code for Progress, Girl Develop It, DC Web Women, AIGA, General Assembly and more!) to help you advance your technical skills. Get ready for an October filled with workshops and events to help beginners learn how to code and design!  Follow @DCFemTech for updates and sign up to get the latest with the Tech Lady Newsletter.


Join us for a Kick off Celebration for the DCFT Tour de Code!  Our friends at Google DC are hosting, (they're kick ass hosts!), and it promises to be a great evening!  Come meet representatives from all the different WIT organizations and phenomenal people in our community! 

Please RSVP on nvite (link below).  RSVPing on this meetup DOES NOT RSVP you to the event.  Although this is a free event, space is limited and we're really hoping to fill it so RSVP on nvite and come JOIN US! 

https://nvite.com/DCFemTechTDC/eb6


Hope to see you there!
name: DCFemTech Tour de Code!

description:
MoDev is back in October with a Wearables + Things Conference Oct 20-21! 

Use code GDI14 for a 15% discount on tickets! 

The Wearables + Things conference is two days of essential talks, training, and product demos for anyone developing or designing for the Wearables and Internet of Things ecosystems.  

$14B market for wearables alone in 2014 and more than 100 billion devices connected to the Internet by 2020 confirms that this IS next major technology revolution. From smart watches to connected devices, the leaders are being established and the opportunity for OEMs, developers, designers and service providers is now. Join us at Wearables + Things in October for two days of inspired action and training designed to help you take the reins of this market and ride the wave of the next decade.

Join industry leaders including Adidas, Sony, Amazon, Bluetooth, Intel, and more. See the full schedule and speaker list at modevwear.com


Please visit the conference website to register.  RSVPing here on meetup will NOT register you!
how_to_find_us: 1-2 blocks down from the Rosslyn Metro station
name: MoDev's Wearables + Things Conference

description:
Recruiters notoriously spend an average of six seconds reviewing a resume. Technical recruiters also do not typically have technical training but rely on keywords and a very general understanding of software development to decide which candidates to move forward. 

Sharing her perspective as a technical recruiter, Chelsea Cohen will discuss best-practices when it comes to creating a technical resume that will appeal to recruiters along with ways to make yourself more "findable" online. 

We will go over resume content (including objectives/summaries and keywords) and format as well as social media/branding ideas to help you stand out as a rockstar developer to the non-technical "technical" recruiter. 


About the teacher

As the Founder of Synaptic Talent, LLC, Chelsea Cohen helps leading technology and finance firms enhance their technical workforce. She learned the tools of her trade first hiring quants for a New York City hedge fund and then recruiting software engineers for Google. She received her master's degree in Human Development and Psychology from the Harvard Graduate School of Education and loves combining her education and recruiting backgrounds whenever possible to help more women enter and flourish in tech and finance. Find out more about her business at SynapticTalent.com, follow her on Twitter @synaptictalent, or connect with her on LinkedIn.


Google is graciously hosting us in their new DC office!  They are also generous enough to provide food & drinks for attendees!  Please take a minute to send a huge thanks via Twitter (@google), G+, or whatever your fave social media platform is to them for being awesome to us! 

Requirements

Please bring your laptop and a copy of your resume to class!  We'll be working based off actual resumes to provide feedback.  

Parking:

There is nearby garage or street parking if you are driving.  Alternately, you can take the metro to the Union Station metro station on the red line.  The office is only a block and a half away.

Refund Policy: Your payment guarantees your seat in the course. If something changes after registration and you cannot attend the course, your seat is yours to sell or give to someone else - just please let us know who!  As a rule we don't offer refunds or credits;  Instead your class fee will go toward our chapter fund which we will use to establish a scholarship fund going forward.   That said, please do reach out and let us know if you have extenuating circumstances.
name: Tech Resume Writing Workshop

description:
There will be two 30-45 minute sessions + open discussion and Q&A. Tech topics will be selected soon. Watch this page for details.


You are encouraged to bring your projects, ask for help on any tech related topic, or just chill and enjoy the event.

description:
Have you ever wondered how to add interactive behavior to an otherwise bland, static HTML CSS page? It is now time to take your webpage a step ahead with JavaScript!

We're a group of women who want to learn JavaScript together. The study group is intended for everyone who wishes to learn JavaScript programming language, it's perfect for beginners with a basic understanding of HTML & CSS, and since there is no prior installation required, JavaScript is hassle free to get started with and fun to create something that’s easy to share with friends. If you already know JavaScript, this can be a great platform for you to get together with fellow developers and hone your skills. If you're advanced, we'd love for you to come and help others learn more.

JavaScript Study Groups are relaxed and informal, so it doesn't matter if you are a fast or slow learner, or if you attend every week. It is a great platform for you to be able to work and play together, while providing each other with ongoing support and feedback. 

There's always at least one mentor present to help you with best practices or guide you through if you are stuck with a nasty problem!


Want to be a JavaScript Study Group leader? 

If you are passionate about learning JavaScript with fellow awesome women and want to help us, come on out!  Shoot me a message or mail me and let me know that you are interested in helping us with the JS study group! 

RESOURCES

These are the resources that members have been following along, feel free to suggest if you have more to add!

Coursera  
http://www.codecademy.com/tracks/javascript-combined

JavaScript is Sexy  
http://javascriptissexy.com/how-to-learn-javascript-properly/

Codecademy  
http://codecademy.com/

Bentobox for references
http://www.bento.io/

JavaScript Official Guide
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript

JSFidlle- create/edit/test/share HTML CSS JS code
http://jsfiddle.net/

<a href="http://codecademy.com/"></a>
name: Front End Hack Night

name: Front End Hack Night

description:
Interested in learning to code, but don't know where to start?  Have an idea for a web application or an app, but aren't sure what the best platform is to build it in? Do you want to learn what the differences are between Python, Ruby,  HTML, Java, Javascript, and the dozens of other terms you hear when people talk about technology?

This meetup will introduce you to a lot of the common terms that developers often forget can be so confusing when you first start out. We will be starting from the ground up to explain what languages are useful for, and what makes them different from each other.

This event is perfect for beginners to help determine what coding "path" you want to start out with. It could also be very useful for a developer that wants to expand her high-level understanding of new languages!
name: The Language of Languages

name: Front End Hack Night

description:
Have you ever lost code and been really frustrated? Have you needed a line you wrote two days ago but saved over? Maybe you want to code with other people but are tired of sending zip files back and forth via email? Are you just getting started coding and want to learn best practices for how and where you should save it?

This meetup will introduce you to Git, a version control system. This event is perfect for beginners as we'll show you the tool many developers use to collaborate and back up code. If you're a developer and you are not using a version control system, you should come out too as it's an absolute must for a developer's workflow.

This event will be hands-on, so we encourage you to bring your laptops as we'll be doing real examples and practicing together. If you want to get ahead of the curve, you can sign up for a free account over at Github.com and start reading some of their documentation.
name: Intro to Git

description:
Have you ever wondered how to add interactive behavior to an otherwise bland, static HTML CSS page? It is now time to take your webpage a step ahead with JavaScript!

We're a group of women who want to learn JavaScript together. The study group is intended for everyone who wishes to learn JavaScript programming language, it's perfect for beginners with a basic understanding of HTML & CSS, and since there is no prior installation required, JavaScript is hassle free to get started with and fun to create something that’s easy to share with friends. If you already know JavaScript, this can be a great platform for you to get together with fellow developers and hone your skills. If you're advanced, we'd love for you to come and help others learn more.

JavaScript Study Groups are relaxed and informal, so it doesn't matter if you are a fast or slow learner, or if you attend every week. It is a great platform for you to be able to work and play together, while providing each other with ongoing support and feedback. 

There's always at least one mentor present to help you with best practices or guide you through if you are stuck with a nasty problem!


Want to be a JavaScript Study Group leader? 

If you are passionate about learning JavaScript with fellow awesome women and want to help us, come on out!  Shoot me a message or mail me and let me know that you are interested in helping us with the JS study group! 

RESOURCES

These are the resources that members have been following along, feel free to suggest if you have more to add!

Coursera  
http://www.codecademy.com/tracks/javascript-combined

JavaScript is Sexy  
http://javascriptissexy.com/how-to-learn-javascript-properly/

Codecademy  
http://codecademy.com/

Bentobox for references
http://www.bento.io/

JavaScript Official Guide
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript

JSFidlle- create/edit/test/share HTML CSS JS code
http://jsfiddle.net/

<a href="http://codecademy.com/"></a>
name: Front End Hack Night

description:
This month we'll feature demos of three new tools that approach mapping in new and interesting ways. Come out to see them in action presented in five minute lightning talks. Here's our lineup:

• Stephanie Nguyen will demo Landmark, a mobile app from Silica Labs for intuitive walking directions focused on photos of landmarks, not maps. Landmark combines beautiful photos with a strong crowdsourcing community who are passionate about their city and the architecture around them, all to provide directions in a different way.

• Karl Phillips will show his work mapping historical changes in cities around the country and demo how he's using MapStory to crowdsource this work and release the data openly.

• Jon Nordling will show off the Geographical Open Data Kit, a mobile data collection and storing platform for geo-referenced information that's fully open source.

• Trevor Gerhardt will demo <a>CarFreeAtoZ</a>, a commute planner Conveyal has been building for Arlington under their Transit Tech Initiative, and will talk about using <a>OpenTripPlanner's</a> journey profiler and using public census data to analyze accessibility in a region.


Come out at 7pm to grab a drink and bite to eat. We'll kick off introductions and lightning talks at 7:30pm. There will be time after to talk with our speakers and everyone else. Stetsons is a 21 and over venue. If you're not yet 21 but want to attend, message us via meetup and we'll do our best to get you in. 

GeoDC meets on the first Wednesday of the month to learn, network, and talk about the work people are doing with maps, GIS, geodata, and more. Join this meetup group, follow <a>@Geo_DC</a> on Twitter, and join our Google group for updates.


Do you have something you'd like to share with the group? Let us know!
name: October GeoDC: Demos

description:
Sometimes it's nice to take a break from the digital screens of our lives and bust out the pen and paper. Join us for an evening of drawing and tracing beautiful maps at this special Maptime.

Inspiration and activities here: https://github.com/ddai/hand-drawn-maps Don't forget to bring your art supplies: sharpies, markers, crayons, highlighters, etc!

**

Maptime is, rather literally, time for mapmaking. Our mission is to open the doors of cartographic possibility to anyone interested by creating a time and space for collaborative learning, exploration, and map creation using mapping tools and technologies.

This open learning environment for all levels and degrees of knowledge offers intentional support for the beginner. Maptime is simultaneously flexible and structured, creating space for workshops, ongoing projects with a shared goal, and independent/collaborative work time.

Inspiration for Maptime comes from both hack nights and knitting circles. Both are models of spaces for people to create and learn together. Our goal is to provide this space with an open heart and without pretension. You can bring your own projects to work on, or just hang out and socialize or ask questions. Some people are experts, and some people are just getting started, but all of us are learning, so why not do it together?

For more information about Maptime, visit maptime.io. Also, follow us on twitter at @MaptimeDC.
name: Maptime: Hand-Drawn Maps 101
